The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: Eqyptians and English
div.p: New books on Eqypt appearing with such startling frequency, that one can hardly find time or space to review many of them. We have quite lately referred at some length to two important books, but the one under noticed by Mustapha Pacha Kamel, will not require such an effort. One cannot help asking whether it is probable that so many books can last. As to some, there may be much difference of opinion, but not so, we venture to think, with this particular book, which suggests to us the simile of a frail bark, built of materials well-nigh rotten before they were not put together, and covered with so thin a coat of varnish that it could not hope to float long on the sea of adverse currents and contrary winds, on which it has been launched. The book begins with a preface written by a French Lady wh enjoys a considerable literary reputation, but she has been in Egypt as a tourist, and our readers know only too well what the lady tourist can write on Egypt. It has often been said that the most important part of a lady's letter is generally in the postscript, and we think that this preface is no exceptiom to teh rule, for it tells ust hat the author of the book was only twenty-one years old when he delivered his first political oration at Toulouse in 1895; for the book consists of the reproduction of about a dozen political speeches made by the author between that date and 1904, and all of them on the same subject-- the abuse of the English occupation of Egypt. We are thus informed that the author was only eight years old at the time of the "events" in 1882, so that his personal experience of a previous state of things in Egypt could only of the very slightest; had it been greater, he would have known that if he or any of his countrymen had then dared,in the times to which he looks back with so much regret, to air their political opinions, with the same freedom which he has used, he would promptly have found himself up the White Nile or in some Egyptian prison from which he would have brought away lively recollections of personal discomfort. From further infromation we gather that the author, soon after he had finished wth the milk bottle, was sent t Frnace to imbibe knowledge at a seat of learning which was in those days a hotted for the cultivation of anti-english notions, and when he returned there, at the age of 21, the value of his own personal experience in this country could hardley be set at a very high figure. He wad cerainly gifted with very considerable fluency of speech, but he seems to forget, or tobe but little grateful for the fact, that it was only the fortunate circumstance of an English occupation which permitted him to make use of what in most Oriental countries is considered a very obnoxious qualification.

Our readers will appreciate the author's meagre personal experience; this might have been backed up by historical research as to the circumstances of otehr foreign occupations of this and other countries. Before he oublishes a second edtion we would recommend the author to read Napoleon's correspondence on the French occupation of Egypt, and the history of the first twenty years of their occupation of Augiere. From the first he would find that after a slight disturbance in Cairo, which had been out down with an iron hand, Napoleon writes to his General there to contine to cut off a few heads every day for some time, so as to maintain a proper amount of respect; from the second he would read of deeds of cruelty which might well make him shudder. Let him compare these with the state of Egypt during the last 24 years -- but fortunately the British occupation of Egypt does not want such an apologist as the author might have been, if better informed. Thst he should have published such a book 8 or 10 years ago would not have astonished us, but now that the "entente cordiale" has fortunately torn away the veil, through which our friends the French saw Egypt only dimly for so mant years, surely it is too late for the autor to expect that his visionary speeches can be of much interest. The "entente cordiale" must have indeed been a bitter pill to the atuhor; and when in addition to this he sees the rapid strides of improvement and progress in this country during the last few years, which even the casual observeer can recognize as only the first fruits of the harvest, the author must now realize that he in entirely out of tune with his surroundings. We understand that it is from Turkey that he derives his dignity of Pacha; in that less favoured country he would find a more fitting field for his genius, for which this country can no longer afford sufficient scope; he could well be spared here for he is only one of the drones who interfere with the working of the hive. We think the author would have been better advised not have been better advised not to have publised his book at all, but if he wished it to be widely read he certainly made a great mistake in putting the price so high as frs. 3.50.

The new Lord Chancellor made a powerful reply to Lord Milner supporting the policy of the Government.
Mr. Balfour's majority of 11340 constitutes a record for this election.

The management of the Savoy Hotel has fixed the date of the fancy dress ball for Tuesday next, March 6. Everybody remembers that last year's Savoy fancy-dress ball was one the best functions of the season, and this year's will no doubt be equally succesful.

The masked ball given yesterday evening, on the occasion of Shrove Tuesday, by the Valetta Maltese National Band at its rooms, was a great success. div.head: Egyptian Estates. Another Big Deal. Purchase of Hotel Du Nil
div.p: The Egyptian Estates, Limited, have concluded another most important transaction, by which the Cairo Hotel du Nil. of world wide fame—having been founded in 1836—will after the close of this reason pass into the hands to the company, who have acquired the property not for hotel purposes but for development as a building estate. The property comprises over 7.300 pics and is situated right in the heart of the Monsky, within a stone's-throw of property I which has recently changed "Lands at L.E. 65 a metre.
We understand that the terms on which the Egyptian Estates have acquired this valuable building property are such that a large profit will accrue therefrom.

div.head: The Price of Land
div.p: We learn that the Egyptian Land Investment Company has sold the land formerly occupied by the Autofage engineering works in Alexandria at the price of about L.E. 30,900, which represents a profit to the company, realized in a few months, of close on L.E. 11,000. This is one of the many proofs of the increasing value of land in Alexandria and of property in general in Egpyt.

div.head: Egyptian Constructions, LTD.
div.p: The subscription list of this company will close at 5 p.m. to-day punctally. Up to the time of going to press the capital had been subscribed nearly six times over.

div.head: Extension of Penny Postage
div.p: With effect from the 1st March, the postage on letters for Gilbraltar, the United Colony of Trinidad, Tobago, and the Transvaal will be reduced and fixed at 5 milliemes for every 15 grammes or fraction therof.

Therefore, up to the present the reduction of postage has been adopted with: the United Kingdom, New Zealand, British India (including Aden), the Straits Settlements, Malta, Cyprus, Bermuda, Bahamas, Gibraltar, the United Colony of Trinidad, Tobago, and the Transvaal.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H.H. the Khedive is expected to arrive in Alexandria on his return from his trip to the Western desert next Sunday. Shortly after his arrival his Highness will proceed to Cairo, where he will grant an audience to Muzaffar Bey and Febmy Bey, the two Ottoman offical, who, it is reported in the native Press, have been isntructed to dicuss the Akaba question with his Highness personally.

div.head: The Hohenzollern.
div.p: Considerable anxiety prevailed in Alexandria yesterday owing to the non-arrival of the Norddeutscher Lloyd S.S. Hohenzollern, which was due on Monday morning from Marseilles and Naples, with such distinguished passengers on board as the Archduke Jospeph and the Archduchess Augusta of Austria.

Fears as to the safety of the ship were dispelled yesterday eveing, when a telgram was recieved stating that the Hohenzollern had pur into Suda Bay owing to her crank-shaft having been broken. All were reported to be well on board, and the passengers will be brought on to Alexandria by the same company's S.S. Schleswig, which will call at Suda on her way and will arrive on Monday next.

div.head: The School Strike. Absurd Claims. Other Schools Come Out.
div.p: The insubordination which has culminated in the strike at the Khedival Law School, Cairo, has been simmering for the last ten days and finally came to a head on Sunday, when the pupils decided to go out in a body.

Some of the students appear to have made certain complaints are the new regulations, to which the Ministry of Public Instruction paid no attention, and the punishment of certian pupils of the third class for an infraction of discipline caused further ill-feeling.

Five pupils next got into trouble for nonattendance at lectures etc., and were forbidden to enter for the examinations at the end of the year. This decision resulted in a strike which spread from the first class throughout the school. Mr. Archibald the sub-director, called upon the strikers to choose three delegates to out their complaints befire the authorities, They replied by choosing twenty-four, who presented a kind of manifesto containing eleven demands, a sort of declaration of the rights of the pupil with no reference to his duties. The demands were--
1. That no pupil be forbidden to enter for these examinations, to be allowed the right of entering for them.
2. Pupils, already forbidden to enter for the examninations, to be allowed the right of entering for them.
3. That pupils should only be examined on subjects included in the courses.
4. That each pupil, who fails in the examination for a higher class at the end of the year, should be allowed to take it again.
5. No afternoon school.
6. A week to be allowed the students for recapitulation before the examinations at the end of the year.
7.. that the school doors should not be closed during the courses and that pupils should be allowed to enter or leave the school at any time.
8. That marks for attendance and diligence should not be counted in the examination at the end of the yeat.
9. That a Commission be formed for the examination of the 1st class.

10. The pupils are resolved not to return to the school till these claims are satisified. In consequence their delegates will attend at the school for an hour daily to await the answer of the authorities.
11. The Political Economy course to be altered.

M. Grandmoulin, the director of the Law School agreed to lay these demands--with the exception of No. 10--before the authorities. The Students answered in effect. "All or nothing!" and decided to continue the strike. Meetings in the Cairo public gardens are attended by large and enthusiastic parties of the strikers, and it appears that orators who have no connection with the schools have urged them to continue their resistance.

The pupils of the School of Medicine and the Polytechnic talk of sending a petition to the Ministry of Public Instruction demanding that the conditions claimed by the strikers should be carried out. If matters stop ther not much harm will be done, but we are informed that a number of these young people threaten to start a sympathetic strike in imiation of the law students unless the Government agrees to the demands of the latter. We can only express the hope that they will think better of it at the last moment and that the strikers and their supporters will realize that it is absurd to dream that the Ministry will or can comply with such mad demands as those we hae given above. The partisans of the extension of Higher Education in Egypt will not be encouraged by the fact that students representing the pick of the Government secondary schools can make such imbecile claims. Are boys to be allowed to run in and out of their classes whenever they please! Are they to do no afternoon work when three days in the weeka re half-holdidas! Do they seriously expect that pupils will be allowed to take the same examination and fail year after year? The idea is absurd.

We are informed that in consequence of resolutions passed at a meeting held by the students of the Law School yesterday, and attended by delegates from the Polytechnic School and the School of Medicine, the pupils of the latter schools decided to go on strike, as a mark of their sympathy with the claims of the law students. The meeting held yesterday was extremely animated, an English lady, who rashly endeavoured to say a few words, being hooted down and insulted by the products of the Higher Education in Egypt.

div.head: Congo and Egypt. False Rumours. Situation on Frontier Unchanged.
div.p: We understand that there is no truth whatever in the rumours either of a collision between the Egyptian and Congolese forces on the frontier or in the neighborhood of Mesbra el-Rek.

From all accounts the situation on the Congo frontier remains entirely unchanged The Beglian forces have not withdrawn from the posts established by them to the north of the Sudan frontier, and the pacific boycott enforced by the Sudanese authorities continues.

div.head: The Frontier Question
div.p: The Turkish Commissioners who arrived here on Saturday have not yet opened negotiations with the Egyptian Authorities in Regard to the frontier dispute.
We understand that all is quiet at Tabah and that no forward movement of Turkish troops has taken place.

div.head: Wedding At Port-Said Norman-Yearly
div.p: A large and fashionable, congregation assembled at the English Church this morning for the marriage of Mr. James Norman, manager of Messrs., Savon end Co., Suez (late of Messrs., Cory Brothers and Co., Ld.) to Miss Yearly, of the Lady Stranfords Hospital, Port Said. The church was well filled long before the hour announced for the ceremony.

A large and fashionable, congregation assembled at the English Church this morning for the marriage of Mr. James Norman, manager of Messrs., Savon end Co., Suez (late of Messrs., Cory Brothers and Co., Ld.) to Miss Yearly, of the Lady Stranfords Hospital, Port Said. The church was well filled long before the hour announced for the ceremony. The bride, who was given away by Miss Stiff, matron of the hospital looked very charming in a pretty rich satin gown trimmed with lace, with a tulle veil over a wreath of orange blossoms. There were many other pretty dresses which gave colour to the church Mr. Cheseman acted as "best-man." The service was impressively conducted by Canon Strange. A reception was afterwards held at the Eastern Exchange. Later in the morning the newly- wedded couple left for Cairo, where the honeymoon will be spent.

div.head: Khedivial Opera House. La Tosca.
div.p: A very good performance. The title-role was in the capable hands of Sigra, Bellincioni, who sang beautifully throughout. But we were even more struck by her superb acting, which called for special mention in Acts II. And III. Sigr. Giovanni Polese as Scarpia was heard to great advantage, and his magnificent voice. to force his voice, wonderfully rich in tune, delighted all his hearers. His rendering of the part was particulary fine. Sigr. Jose Palet in the first act was at times almost completely drowned by the orchestra, and in order to be heard was obliged to force his voice. This should not be the case. Occasionally the conductor seemed to lose sight of the foot that his orchestra was accompanying—a most common fault. Nevertheless Sig. Palet sustained the role of Mario with artistic feeling and his singing of the famous solo in the last act was one of the best rendered items in the whole opera.

div.head: St. Catherin's College; AMATEUR THEATRICALS IN ENGLISH.
div.p: One of the enjoyable entertainments which are given periodically by the Christian Brothers for the amusement of parents and friends, as well as the pupils of their school, took place on Tuesday, and the large crowd of spectators present clearly amplified the popularity in which these performances are held. Certainly in no other institution of the kind here is the progress of the English language amongst younger Alexandria more forcibly demonstrated than in the excellent performances of English plays, operettas, and even Christy Minstrels, by these bright youngsters, for the parts we almost invariably supported bv young actors to whom the English language is absolutely foreign.

Tuesday's performance, which was under he distinguished patronage of M. Pierre Girard, Consul-General for France, was fully up to the usual standard and kept the audience in continual merriment The first part of the entertainment consisted of a play in one act entitled ' A Sadden Arrival" and in which all the characters were exceedingly well portrayed. The songs were well sung choruses rendered with spirit, and the piece went with a verve seldom excelled by amateurs much older than our youthful "mummers." As has been the case for several years, this stage-management was in the able and either hands of Mr. J Pearson-Hill.
The boys who took part and who were all equally successful in their respective rolls were Masters Z. Simika, M. Perdikides, T. Sitton A. Rathl, G. Saunier, H. Lehan, and S. Stanos.

div.p: MALEH'S FASHIONABLE HOTEL; PATRONISED BY THE ELITE. Full Pennsieh from P.T. a day. Visitors from Cairo flight at Sidi-Gaher station.

div.head: Cairo Amusements. Carnival Pranks. Comparison with the Riviera.
div.p: A correspondent writes to us as follows-- The attempt to naturalise the products of the Riviera in Cairo—I refer to the recent Battle of Flowers and the still more recent "Corso Fieuri" is considered by some to be worthy of support and is certainly being boomed for all It Is worth by the Committee of Fetes and the local Press. But I should like your permission to point out that there is a vast differences between the Riviera and Cairo, and that diversions that are popular end amusing enough at Monte Carlo are likely to become in every sense "impossible" in the Egyptian Capital, A friend, whose knowledge of Europe is extensive end peculiar, remarked to me shortly after Sunday's entertainment, that snob performances ware only tolerable in places like Monte Carlo, where the population during the season was composed for the most part of French demi-moudaines and South American rastoqueres. The former looked so ornamental and the latter threw about their own (and other people's) money with such lavish prodigality that Corsos and similar entertainments were picturesque and popular.

The recent open air entertainments given by the Committee of have emphatically not been picturesque. I admit that a few wall decorated carriages or well-designed groups were to be seen at each, but one swallow, or half a dozen for that matter, does not make a summer, and the spectacle of a decrepit arabieh, decorated by three bunches of wilted violets and surmounted by a consumptive palm, driving an overdressed and semi Oriental family round and round a grandstand, does not in the least impress me. Nor do I care to be pelted in the streets by the wrong sort of people.

The class that hurls confetti in the Riviera is composed of persons who, whatever their moralsand they are good enough in many cases—pay an outward and visible respect for the convenances and play the fool in loco like civilised beings. On Sunday, parties of enthusiastic Levantine shop-boys, reinforced by a polyglot contingent of waiters bottle- washers, carried the confetti battle from Ghezireh into the Cairo streets. Here is one of their performances. On the afternoon of the last fete a carriage with two ladies drove up to the Khedivial Club and stopped, one of the ladies being, I believe, anxious to leave a line for her husband. At this moment a carried crammed with youths dressed up as Arab women stopped beside them and its inmates pelted both the ladies, who were going out to call, with handfuls of hard confetti and dust. Now, if I want to have confetti thrown down my neck I go to Ghezireh knowing my fate: but if I decline the pleasure I expect to escape their attentions when I am walking about the streets of Cairo. By all means allow people to throw confetti at the right time and in the right place, but for heaven's sake let us be free from the risk of having confetti, probably swept up with the other debris of recent orgies, flung into our faces while we shop, stroll or visit. Of course the Committee of Fetes has perfect right to organize beanfeasts where waiters and shop boys can enjoy themselves, but I submit that these are not the sort of entertainments to which tourists, who have monthly seen "the real thing" properly done and residents who have a certain amount of taste, are likely to patronize in large numbers.

div.head: Notes from Mena
div.p: While all Cairo Society is enjoying the rivalry of fashion, Mena House is continuing the more healthy pleasures of country life and sport. Cricket matches, golf handicaps, paper-chases exchange each other with excursions in the desert, picnic parties, etc., and since the weather out here is so delightful the hotel is full and there is never a single room disengaged. On Sunday last many people came out luncheon, to such an extent that the big during hall had the appearance of a Gymkhana day, and in the afternoon many people drove up in carriages to spend a few hours in the pleasant hotel gardens or on the terrace where Bracale's band was performing. On Monday morning Lady Cromer and lady Beatrice Thynn, with the Hon. Evelyn Baring and suite, came out to Mena House, to take advantage of the beneficial air for the young child, who is now convalescent Lady Cromer will remain here for some time.
The small dance on Monday was a great success. Bracale's orchestra performed both at dinner and for the dance.

div.head: Sudan Agriculture. Cotton and Wheat. Export of Sudan Produce.
div.p: The Globe's Cairo correspondent writes—The festivities at Khartoum have their Instructive side, as was doubtless intended by Lord Cromer, who, together with his lieutenants, desires the truth as to the Sudan and its resources to be known in Egypt and abroad from other lips than his own. The guests of the Egyptian Government have seen with their own eyes, and the account published by one of their number is of extreme interest. Sir Reginald Wingate considers that the crops most suitable for growing at present are wheat and cereals in general. The Administration has established an experimental farm, where trials of various kinds of crops are carried out. Greek enterprise, as on the Mediterranean littoral of Egypt and throughout the Delta, is to the forefront in Khartoum. M. Capatos, a Greek cultivator, offers the relatively high price of £45 the acre for crop bearing land, with agricultural implements included in the purchase. On his property in the neighborhood of Khartoum, M Capatos has founded a veritable agricultural colony, and erected a cotton ginning mill equipped with modern plant. A visit was paid to his estate. The soil was found to be abundantly fertile, and planted with cotton of the mit afifi, abbassi, and Johannovitch varieties, all of which, together with the cereal crops, were thriving. According to the generous customs of the country, a couple of oxen were slaughtered in honour of the guests, the flesh being distributed among the poor.

It is estimated that the export of Sudan produce during 1906 will amount to 50,000 tons, By 1900 it is calculated that the total export should attain 100 000 tons. As regards Sudan wheat, authorities at Khartoum consider it as being of much superior quality to that grown in Egypt.

div.head: Obituary. Vice-Admiral Grensfell
div.p: The death occurred with painful suddenness last week of Vice Admiral Sir Harry Tremenheere Grenf B. K.C.B., C.M.G., second in command in the Mediterranean Fiest. The vice-admiral had recently returned home on sick leave, having left Malta on January 31 in the hospital ship Maine and landed at Marseilles on February 6. It was confidently hoped that he would be able to return and rehoist his flhag on board the Venerable.

Sir Harry Grenfell who was born in March, 1845, was a son of Admiral John Pascoe Grenfell, of the Imperial Brazilian Navy. He entered the Royal Navy in 1858 and was made a lieutenant in March, 1866. His promotion to commander came as a haul down vacancy in 1876, and in this rank he commanded the Cockatrice during the Egyptian war, 1882, receiving the Egyptian medal and the Khedive's bronze star. In 1892 he invented the night sights for ordinance. His commission as captain was dated February 4, 1896, adn when commanding the Benhow he gallantly jumped overboard to rescue a boy who was in danger of drowing, and with the assistance of another officer supported the lad until they were all picked up by a boat. During the operations in Crete, 1896 97, he commanded the Royal Sovereign, and for his services on this occasion received the C.M.G. in 1900. In March of that year he was raised to flag rank, and in September, 1901 hoisted his flag in the Barfleur as second in command on the China Station, afterwards shifting it to the Albion. After a period of two years on that station he returned to England, and in October, 1904, was appointed second in command in the Mediterranean, with his flag in the Venerable. In February of last year he became a vice-admiral, and in June was made a K.C.B.
Sir Harry Grenfell married in 1871 Amy, a daughter of Mr. Andrew Law, of Savannah, Georgia, U.S.A.

Les offre devront etre accompagnees d'une feuille de papier timbre de 30 Milliemes Elles seront adressees par la poste sous pli recomande a: "Monsieur le Directeur General Chemins de fer de l'Etat Caire." et sous double enveloppe, l'interieure portant la suscription suivante:--

L'Administration ne s'engage pas a accepter l'offre la plus basse, ni a donner suite aux soumissions presentees, et elle se reserve le droit de diviser la commande.

div.head: "England Expects." The Discovery of Nelson's Famous Memorandum.
div.p: The original draft in Nelson's own handwriting of his famous "General Memorandum," issued to his captains at Trafalgar, has (''The Daily Telegraph" announces) come to light, after a concealment of over a hundred years. This masterpiece of naval strategy— extant in the copies distributed by Nelson to his fleet -has passed into a classic and has probably been translated into the language of every nation possessing a seaboard or a ship.

It has become an article of faith to naval students throughout the world, and, shortly, all Will be privileged to see this precious relic, just as he set the words down, with the corrections, with the deletions, with his rough drawing of his own and the enemy lines of battle at the moment of the "intended attack.''

In James's "Naval History" the memorandum is printed, and to compare this version 'the fair copy) with the original draft is highly instructive. When the representative of "The Daily Telegraph" was permitted to see the Nelson relic he was first struck with the bold, upstanding, and broadside character of the penmanship. Next, he examined the alterations and deletions compare 1 with the fair copy. In the latter occurs early in the Memorandum the sentence, *'The second in command will, after my intentions are made known to him, have the entire direction of his line to make the attack upon the enemy/' andc.

Nelson pennel this originally, "The second in command will, in fact, command his line and," and then struck out the words from "mil" to "and." A very important deletion is the excision of the sentence in speaking of the enemy, "I shall suppose them forty six sail in the line of battle."

Again, the opening of the second paragraph of the Memorandum, the fair occupy runs: "If the enemy's fleet should be seen to windward in line of battle, and that the two lines and the advancing squadron could fetch them, they will probably be so extended that their van could not succour their rear." Nelson wrote "advanced" for advancing,'' and "can" for "could." These are not his corrections; but he corrected to "and that" a sentence beginning, but in that position that" And later, when he wrote, "I should therefore probably make the second in command's signal," he had altered "your" to "second in command." Further, in the sentence, "but I look with confidence to a victory before the van of the enemy could succour their rear," the lost word was altered from "friends."

IN The rough map of the "intended 1 attack" Nelson draw' four parallel lines. Tin top three ha labels "B," the fourth "E." It is common knowledge that the first monument erected to Nelson's fame was raise! in Scotland. In Nelson's map "B" stands for "British," and "E" for "Enemy."

Lastly, as regards these interesting differences and emendations, the following sentence is usually underlined in quoting from the Memorandum, 1 No captain can do very wrong if he places hid ship alongside that of an enemy." Nelson in no way shows that he 'desired these words to be emphasized, noble and inspiring though they be.

Naturally the question will be asked where can this document of such enormous national import be seen. The answer is, at Christie's, in about three weeks time. At present little more can be divulged, save that it has been in the possession of a family living not far from Merton Abbey—' Emma's" home—from which the hero started for the cruise ending in glory and death. The experts in Nelson documents pronounce it indubitably genuine. Mr. Stanhope, a well known authority, is confident that it bears all the insignia of being the real and previous lost relic. With it are other important naval papers belonging to the same family, one of which is a letter by Admiral Sir Thomas Foley, with a sketch map of the Battle of the Nile and a list of ships damaged or "ataunt." Nelson's last latter to Lady Hamilton is in the British Museum. It is unfurnished. For his last completed letter £1,035 was given at Sotheby's in 1904 Some years ago Nelson's autobiography—twenty quarto sheets in his own hand writing—was allowed to go to America.

div.head: The Cotton Operator
div.p: There is a class of speculators in the cotton market who study "straddles,'' and prefer that kind of risk to what are called, straight risks." whether bailor bear. The general operator as a rule neglects straddles or does not understand them, but they present certain chances of profit or loss, whether the market rises or falls in price. Straddles are (a "Manchester Guardian" correspondent remarks) sometimes between the New York and Liverpool future markets, some times between the Alexandrian and Liverpool future markets, and sometimes between different months in Liverpool or New York. One feature they have in common—namely, that they are usually done in much larger quantities that "straight business." A man who would hesitate to have 1.000 bales open "bull or bear" on a straight risk will enter into a straddle of 2,000 or 8,000 bales on each side with but little hesitation. The reason is not far to seek The straddler has so balanced his operation by sales in one place of as much as he bough in the other that he does not feel himself in much danger. He is only acting for differences, and since he is prepared to take small differences he must take them on large quantifies .

Experience has shown that the most dangerous kind of straddle is one, say, between Liverpool American futures and Egyptian cotton at Alexandria, especially if the operation begins with sales in Alexandria. The Egyptian crop may turn out larger or smaller quite irresponsive of the yield in America. There are no keener operators anywhere than those of Alexandria, and none quicker to find out that their market is occasionally oversold on straddle operations. When that position occurs they have sometimes driven up their market against shorts in a truly remarkable way, and perhaps while American futures in Liverpool were all the time dropping lower. For such reasons straddles between two different growths of cotton are now rarer than they were, and whether it be American against Suras or American against Egyptian such operations present possibilities of loss which seldom appertain to the more simple kinds of straddle. Of these latter two have lately been in favour at Liverpool. Once was to buy Liverpool 1 and sell New York at a time (some weeks ago) when New York futures were relatively very high in comparison with Liverpool. At that time it was easy to effect this straddle at a difference of 60 points. Of course cotton cannot be imported from New York, taking the different ethics into account for 60 points. Consequently, whenever that market is only 60 points, below Liverpool, March against March or May against May. New York is abnormally high relatively. Straddlers who availed themselves of the opportunity have since closed those straddles at 72 and 75 points difference, as the markets readjusted themselves to a more even relative position.

The other straddle recently in vogue is between the old and new crop positions. The theory is, first, that new crop months have been very high in price compared with all recent seasons, except Mr. Sully's year ; next, that these never has been much difference between new and old crop values at the end of the season, except in years of real scarcity or years of great speculative activity. The appearances this season indicate that, with a million bales of American in stock and big shocks in America, the end of the season will show abundance, and not scarcity. Straddles have, therefore, been ventured up in between July old crop and October new crop by sale of July and purchases of October. Some time ago the differences between these months were from 40 to 45 Liverpool points, and they have since shown profits to those who undertook these risks. Another variant, based on the same theory, is a straddle between August- September and September-October, or selling August-September against purchases of September October. One of the curiosities of this straddle is that these two positions overlap; so that the operator has no need to close until the morning of September 30. This sale of August-September will long before this time have become a "September alone." and his argument is that on September 30 if not long before, there can be no such difference in price between September alone and September October as the difference at which he started the operation. This variety of straddle could be started a short time ago at 20 to 25 points of difference. To-day it is 14 or 15 points difference, and the draft seems to be to diminish those differences further. In fact, if these differences were to diminish and disappear altogether it would only be what they have more than once done before.

div.head: Lord De Clifford's Romantic Marriage
div.p: ' The romantic marriage of Lord de Clifford with Miss Eva Carrington, who up to recently was placing in "Bluebell in Fairyland" at the Aldwych Theatre, London, the news of which event was telegraphed by our London Correspondent, has created a great flutter in society circles at home. _

It was a very brief and romantic courtship which led up to the marriage. Last September Miss Carrington was playing at the Gaiety Theatre, Dublin, with Mr. Hicks's company. One night Lord de Clifford occupied a box, and was greatly struck with the grace and personal attraction of the young actress, who is over six feet in height, very stately, and with many accomplishments. She was an exceedingly attractive figure on the stage, for her features are classical in their beauty, and her hair is a mass of lovely brown curls. She had been with Mr. Seymour Hicks for the last six years. From the first she was a favourite, and according to those who know her best, was marked out for a successful career on the stage. Very soon after Lord de Clifford saw her for the first time a meeting was arranged, and at subsequent meetings Lord de Clifford was increasingly impressed by the charms of Miss Carrington. While she remained in Ireland they frequently saw each other. Miss Carrington subsequently returned to London, and was quickly engrossed in her part of "Major Domo" in "Bluebell," at the Aldwyoh Theatre. Lord de Clifford came to Cairo, and there thought much of Miss Carrington Recently he returned to London, and at once sought out Miss Carrington. The next day he offered himself as her husband, and was accepted.

Lord de Clifford, who is a typical specimen of the young military officer, tall and finely got up, was formerly a lieutenant in the Shropshire Imperial Yeomanry, and has more recently been in command of a detachment at Cairo. The first Baron de Clifford was Robert, second Lord of Westmorland, who was summoned to Parliament 1299, was Earl Marshal of England in 1307, was Warden of Scotland in 1308, and was killed at Bannockburn. The family has given England many gallant soldiers, and has for its motto the fatalistic "What will be, will be " The present Lord de Clifford succeeded to the title when he was ten years- of age.

In an interview at St Albans with a representative of the "Star," Lord de Clifford said : "We were married at the St Pancras Registrar's Office, yesterday, very quietly; there were only two witnesses. We motored down here last night, but shall not stay here long. We are going on to-day in the motor to stay somewhere else." In reply to a comment on the unsuitability of the weather for a motor honeymoon, his Lordship said, 'Yes, beastly weather for motoring, isn't it! but I am very happy." The interviewer asked the bridegroom whether he was going to be remarried at St. Margaret's, Westminster, on Monday, as. had been reported. Lord de Clifford replied that he did not know himself yet; it depended upon a telegram he expected to receive from his solicitor, the Hon. Charles Russell. He added: "At any rate, I shall leave England on Monday for Egypt, I am very fond of travel, arid have travelled all over the world, spending thus nearly all my life since I left school." When asked when ho' first met his bride, Lord de Clifford said: "It really seems so long ago that I cannot remember. It is a love match pure and simple."

The stage has often produced similar romances, and among other famous marriages of actresses to peers will be remembered those of Miss Connie Gilchrist, who became the Countess of Orkney; Miss Rosie Boote, who wedded the Marquess of Headfort; and Miss Belle Bilton, who married Viscount Dunlo, now Earl of Clancarty.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny. Notes Et Critiques
div.p: A Londres, le Consilide anglais a encore baisse de 1/3 a 90 3/8. L'Unifies, la National Bank la Daira Sanieh et l'Agricole sont restes invariees a leurs cours precendents.
A Paris, l'action Credit Foncier Egyptien a flechi de 1 franc a 792. la Banque d' Athenes est Demeuree inchangee a 143.

Sur notre marche de valeurs, es nouvelles politiques continent a exercer leur influence sur certains titres qui sout delaisses prudement par la speculation. Ainsi la National Bank et l'Agricole restent plus ou moins a leurs cours precendents.
Le Credit Foncier est reste a 793. Par contre, la Daira Sanieh, en bonne tendance, a avance a 18, gagnant 3/8 de livre sur le prix de la veille.
Le Behera a egalement hausse de 34 1/7 a 36 L'Union Fonciere s'est inscirte a 6 5/16. LA Delta Light a atteint 12.
L'Immobiliere a progresse de 368 a 375. L'action Enterprise and Development a fait 12 1/2; la part de fondateur reste a 13 acheteurs. Les Ciments ont avance a 89 le dividende a 22.
Plusieurs affsires ont ete traitees en actions Societe d'Entreprises Immobilieres et de Travaux entre 2 15/16 et 4; la part de fondateur est a L.E. 7 3/4.
L' action capital Eaux du Caire a'est inscrite a 122-123; les parts de jouissance sont a 278. Le groupe des Hotels est toujours calme.

Parmi les petites valuers, les honneurs de la seance ont ete encore pour les Delta Land, qui ont ete traites a 1 1/8. Les Glymenopoulo ont cloture fermes a 1 13/32 et les Abdy a 1 3/16. Les Oasia sont entre 1 1/8 et 1 3/16. Les Markets sont revenue a 23 vendeurs.

Toutes sortes de rumeurs ont couru hier sici et a Alexandrie, au sujet du mouvemtn de hause qui s'est dessine sur les Salt and Soda. On a parl'e tour a tour de la prolongation de la concession qui, de 6 ans, serait portee a 20 ou 30; de la fusion avec la Port Said Salt Association, qui est pourtant loin d'etre un fait accompli et qui est meme consideree comme une eventualite assex improbable. Toujours est-il que ce titre est revenu aujourd'hui a 26 sh. 9.
D' apres certaines rumeurs, l'EGYPTIAN Estates Co distribuerait pour son premier exercice un dividende de 3 sh. par action et constitu rait un fonds de reserve de non moins de 100,000.
On sjoute, de la meme source, qu'en presence de l'extension des affires de la Societe, il serait question de l'emission procha ne des 250,000 actions restantes.
On Sait que le capital nominal de la Societe est de 500,000, represente par autant d'actions a 1, dont la moitie seulment a ete emise.

En parlant hier de l'Anglo-American Line, nous avions dit que le mouvement de hausse sur ce titre devait etre attribue d'une part, a l'excellente situation de la Societe a la suite de sa fusion avec la Hamburg-Amerika Linie; d'autre part, a la plus-value enorme acquire en ces derniers temps par la propriete de la comganie a boulac, sur les bords du Nil.

De fait, ce terrain d'une superficie de 7,500 metre carres, inscrit au prix coutant (soit 3,500) sur le bilan de l'exercise 1905, vaut bien actuellement, su bas mot, 75,000 en mettant le prix du metre a 10. II resulte donc de ce seul chef un profit de 71,500.

A ce benefice absolument extradordinarure, il faut sjouter le profit derivant des 5,00 actions de la Societe prises a 5 (au lien de 4) par la Hamburg-Amerika Linie, soit 5,000 qui ont ete portees a la reserve.
Celle-ci, qui etait de 12,000, se trouve donc etre de 17,000, et avec les 71,500 precitees de 88,500.

Or, le capital social etant de 140,000, sans obligations ou autres charges, la Societe dispose aujourd'hui avec, le profit de sa reserve, d'un second capital, ce qui, pourrait lui permettre de distribuer un dividende double de celui(8%) qui a ete reparti l'annes derniere.
L'emission de l'Egyptian Constructions Ltd. ouverte hier aux guichets de l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, sea close demain soir.
L'impression generals est de plus favorables et l'on prevoit un grand succes, Si nos reneignements sont xacts, la souscription aurait ete deja couverte plusieurs fois a Alexandrie.
LES COUR de coton cout signales en petite baisse en Amerique. Le Mai a perdu hier 4 points et l'Octobre 6. Les arrivages ont ete de 20,000 contre 25,000.
Le marche de Liverpool est plus ou moins stationnaire. Ici, le Mars, qui a fini soir a 18 1/32. a ouvert ce matin a 18 5/32 pour cloturer a 18 15/16.

div.head: Association Du Commerce Dimportation; Comite De Protection Des Creancers
div.p: Sur l'invitation qui lui en a ete faite paplusiurs negociants de notre ville, l'Association du Commerce d'Importation vient d'elaborer le Reglement d'orginasation d'un "comite de protection des creanciers."

Le nombre toujours croissant des faillites et des concordate preventifs et les difficuktes auxquelles le Commerce se heurts journellement en cette matiere, out fait, naitre l'idee d'une organisation fondee aur la solidarite des creanciers intereses dont le but est d'enrayer dans la meausre du possible les incovenients de la situation actuelle.

Des insitutions semblables fonctionnent en Europe depuis longtemps deja et leurs adherents y ont trouve un auxilaire important, qui leur a rendu possible l'application integrale des garanties edictees en principe par la loi.

Le Comite de l'Associaition du Commerce d'Importation est convaincu que la Comite de Protection des Creaciers" pourra repondre au double but d'utilire et demoralite duquel il s'inspire, et compre que tous adhereront a cette nouvelle orgnaisation.

div.head: Le Prix Des Terrains En Ville
div.p: nous venons d'apprende la vente faite ces jours derniers par "The Egyptian Land Investment Cy" du terrain des anciens Ateliers Autofage au prix de L.E. 30, 900 environ.
La benefice realise en quelques mois par cette societe sur cette affaire est de pres de 11,000 livres.
Volia encore une nouvelle transaction qui met en evidence l'augmentation de la valuer des terrains a Alexandrie et la Prosperite croisante de l'Egypte.

div.head: BULLETIN De la Bourse (Aujourd'hui a midi et demie)
div.p: Le marhce a et tres actif ce matin. Ainsi que nous l'avions prevu dans notre bulletin d'avant-hier, les banques se sont un pen raffermies: la National a 27 1/2 et l'Agricole a 10 1/16. Masi les honneurs de la matinee ont ete pour la Delta Light qui a'est avancee de 12 1/8 a 12 5/8, pour cloture a 12 9/16 en excellenute tendance.

De son cote i'Luvestment, que nous qvions recommande dans notre deruire chronique, alors qu'il etait aut prix de 1 3/32, cloture aujourd'hui a 1 11/32 arhceteure. lA Societe fait prevue d'une grande activite.
En hausse egalement la Behera a 37, la Daira a 18 1/16, l'Union Fonciere a 6 7/16, les Cotten Milis a 6/9 etc.
Par contre, le Comptoir flechit legerement a 5/11/16, l Dalta a 3 1/4, led Estates a 1 27/38, les Markets a 23/3 et les Egyptian Hotels a 4 13/16.
Si les nouvelles poltiques continuent a s'ameliorer, on peut s'attendre a une accentuation sensible de la Hausse.

div.head: Societe Anonyme des Eaux du Caire; Avis
div.p: I1 est porte a la connaissance du ublic que le Conseil d'Administration de la Societe a decide de reduire de 22% le prix de l'eau fournie aux Bornes-fontaines publiques
Eu consequence, a partir du ler Janvier 1906 on pouraa obtenir l'eau aux diters tontaines a raison de P.T. 3 (trois piastres tarif) le metre cube au lieu de P.T. 3,856 payeers jus qui'ici.

Cette reducion de prix ayant ete deciddee par la societe dans le seul but d;en faire profiter les habitants de la ville, le public est prie de veiller a ce que la dite reduction lui soit faite par les sakas qui lui fournuissent l'eau, afin de ne pas laisser ces derniers profiter du rabias qui n'a ete consenti qu'en faveur du public.

La vente d'eau au detail aux Bornes-fontaines a'etablit done comme suit: Le tonneau de 660 kilos de jauge 20 milliemes, la guerbe de 66 ,, ,, 2. L'estagnon de 22 ,, ,, 3/4 ,, et pour toute quantite depassant la jauge cideasus, chawue 4 kilos seront compter a 1/8 de milliemes.
Le Caire le 19 Decembre 1905.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
